name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @TheAtlanticFest: Guests of #TheAtlanticFest 2020 include @Delta CEO Ed Bastian, @eatlearnplay founder @ayeshacurry, the San Francisco district attorney @chesaboudin, and more. Join us, free of charge, for our all-virtual festival from September 21 to 24: https://t.co/knpf2cNtzH https://t.co/x3e9FufrSU

name: TheAtlantic
text: This year’s national reckoning over policing means that more Americans could stand to seriously listen to the music of Drakeo the Ruler and other young rappers who have been incarcerated, Hannah Giorgis writes. https://t.co/ITtp2dINbw

name: TheAtlantic
text: Publishing student writing shifts students from consumers to creators of stories. LaQuisha Hall, a Baltimore educator, has guided more than 100 students to becoming published authors, @mdawriter reports: https://t.co/mdNdoVmMqW

name: TheAtlantic
text: In defeating Joe Kennedy, long-serving Massachusetts senator Ed Markey turned his biggest vulnerability into an opportunity, @russellberman writes: https://t.co/qKVSvchBjk

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @russellberman: “At the very least,” Joe Kennedy told me, “even if I'm not successful, you're going to get a senator that’s going to run the race of his life and be far more connected and far more energized, and far more engaged in Massachusetts.” https://t.co/5W4LFYzZTC

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @AdamHSays: The recent profusion of Black mayors in the South is striking when you consider that, not long ago, there weren't any.

Here's my story from the October issue of @TheAtlantic on the Black mayors charting a path towards a new South: https://t.co/rFxWyOcWL6

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: "The meritocratic age has also inflicted a more insidious injury: eroding the dignity of work. The valorization of those who score well on standardized tests and go on to college or university implicitly disparages those without such credentials."
https://t.co/gMJUDnDvuU

name: TheAtlantic
text: “The events of 2020 have forced these mayors to focus their leadership on day-to-day crisis management,” @AdamHSays writes. “But they remain committed to addressing the underlying inequities that exacerbated the crises.” https://t.co/kNTMEKpwKZ

name: TheAtlantic
text: “A renewed debate about the dignity of work would disrupt our partisan complacencies and morally invigorate our public discourse,” Michael J. Sandel argues. https://t.co/hRmrweHE5l

name: TheAtlantic
text: "What do you do when the free stuff runs out, the businesses and ordinary people who invested in your city decide not to make that mistake again, and—oops!—a few shopkeepers get beaten to death?" @gcaw writes: https://t.co/bpr3rjV8ja

name: TheAtlantic
text: The only English-language single BTS has released in seven years has become their biggest U.S. chart success yet. @lenikacruz on what this milestone means for the South Korean pop group—and for the American music industry: https://t.co/vNR68qyXak

name: TheAtlantic
text: "For a society accustomed to the norms and rhythms of a system designed for humans in rooms together, the tax on students can be hard to fathom," @tesswilkry writes: https://t.co/XNO1Zjv0b2

name: TheAtlantic
text: The yoga teacher Karena Virginia says she was groped by Donald Trump in 1998. Another woman with a similar allegation has chosen to remain anonymous. Both women tell @ejeancarroll their stories and reflect on the aftereffects of their respective decisions: https://t.co/IzSH13sHYa
